subNodes.conversationText: root
<FirstName> stepped out of the vision and into the hunter's clearing. No time had passed. He was still skinning the deer. He held the knife in the same position.
[Continue.]
"So you've come for me."
"Who are you?"
"My name is Wencel. I'm a hunter."
[Continue.]
"Permit me to finish this," he said, still skinning the deer, "I have no children, no kin. Nothing to see finished except this last little bit of work."
"I have," the witch said.
"Permit me to finish this," he said, still skinning the deer, "I have no children, no kin. Nothing to see finished except this last little bit of work."
"No. Put the knife down."
He dropped the knife. "And now, I suppose, you want to see one of my arrows?"
"You know why I'm here?"

"I've had the same dream for as long as I can remember."

"A witch comes to me -- you come to me -- as I skin a deer. We converse. It's not always the same. Sometimes you're cruel, sometimes pitying, sometimes indifferent. I show you an arrow, and then you show me an arrow of the same make, but with blood on it."

"You kill me with my skinning knife."
"I am here for your blood, you know."

He nodded.

"I've run in the woods daily, seen the seasons come and go, had enough to eat and drink. When I was young I had people I loved. In my old age I've grown wise and self-content...

"My dream gave me certainty that few others have. I'm at peace with death and the life I've had."
"Yes."
The hunter's quiver lay in the grass. He picked it up and drew forth an arrow.
[Continue.]

took out the arrow that killed Nnenne and saw it was the twin of the hunter's. The shaft had the same smoothness, the point the same sharpness, and the feathers -- goose feathers -- the same color and arrangement. But there was blood on the witch's.

The hunter said nothing.
"Why did you kill Nnenne?"

There was a pause. The young witch felt suddenly dizzy. Parts of the vision <he/she> had returned -- the hunter, the arrow, Nnenne --, but they were jumbled, stylized, theatrical, the work of an author, not a glimpse of breathing, human conflict.

<He/She> saw the vision of this man stalking Nnenne through the woods over again, but, just as with the vision <he/she>'d experienced with the other hunter, it seemed artificial, an imposition on <his/her> imagination.
"So you deny killing her."
"I do deny killing her -- not for the sake of my life, which I consider forfeit, but because I never did such a thing."
"Can you explain why my arrow matches yours?"
The hunter shook his head.
"Then you must die."
The hunter knelt on the ground, raised his chin, and exposed his throat. "Do it." Knott, who had been standing quietly nearby, apparently unnoticed, shifted.
The witch didn't know what to do.
The hunter knelt on the ground, raised his chin, and exposed his throat. "Do it." Knott, who had been standing quietly nearby, apparently unnoticed, shifted.
The witch sucked in <his/her> breath. "I won't kill you. Not yet."
"If not now, when?"
The witch left the question unanswered.
The man stared at <FirstName>. "My dream --"
"Was false."
"You have unsealed my fate. It's a strange feeling. I can't promise that I'll be here if you change your mind."
"I don't blame you."
The hunter went inside his cabin and shut the door.
"I understand."
The hunter went inside his cabin and shut the door.
"Do not tempt me."
The hunter went inside his cabin and shut the door.
The witch, too, felt liberated from a strange fate.
Then <he/she> went <his/her> way.
[End.]
If this man was Nnenne's killer, this would disappoint the coven, <he/she> knew.
Then <he/she> went <his/her> way.
The witch inwardly condemned <his/her> weakness.
Then <he/she> went <his/her> way.
"Was incomplete."
"You have unsealed my fate. It's a strange feeling. I can't promise that I'll be here if you change your mind."
"Was a dream."
"You have unsealed my fate. It's a strange feeling. I can't promise that I'll be here if you change your mind."
"I'd give it a day at least. Better stand back up."
The man stared at <FirstName>. "My dream --"
"Let me see the arrows you hunt with."
"I don't believe you."
The hunter knelt on the ground, raised his chin, and exposed his throat. "Do it." Knott, who had been standing quietly nearby, apparently unnoticed, shifted.
The witch was ready. <He/She> picked up the skinning knife.
The hunter trembled at the touch of the blade but didn't shrink.
What <he/she> had done was irrevocable and ugly. <He/She> tried to shut it from <his/her> mind but couldn't.

<His/Her> thoughts raced. At least he had been ready. He was at peace with his doom, and his guilt justified his death. It had all been necessary. But uppermost was the conviction that <he/she> needed to find a place to wash the blood off <his/her> hands.
[End.]
<He/She> had done what Eldest Lady asked. <He/She> put the blood away.
Then <he/she> left.
[End.]
<He/She> had done well.
The hunter had foreseen his death in dreams. A vision had shown <FirstName> why he deserved it. His fate was inevitable -- so it seemed, and so the young witch said to <him/her>self.
[End.]
[Continue.]
"I never dreamed how bright the colors would be, how the air would smell when it happened," the man said sadly. "But I'm ready."
[Continue.]

Then, with a swift, sudden motion, <FirstName> slit his throat. Bubbles of blood and spit formed on the man's lips. He shuddered. The witch felt life retreat from his muscles, faltering as it went, a soldier routing from a razed city...

<He/She> let the corpse collapse only after draining it of a pint of blood.
Sorrow overcame <him/her>.

What <he/she> had done was irrevocable and ugly. <His/Her> thoughts raced. The rationalizations papered over the guilt -- he had been ready; he was at peace with his doom; his guilt justified his death -- but the witch's own guilt bled through.
[End.]
<He/She>'d done what Eldest Lady asked. <He/She> put the blood away.
The hunter had foreseen his death in dreams. A vision had shown <FirstName> why he deserved it. His fate was inevitable -- so it seemed, and so the young witch said to <him/her>self.
[End.]
It had been done well.
The hunter had foreseen his death in dreams. A vision had shown <FirstName> why he deserved it. His fate was inevitable -- so it seemed, and so the young witch said to <him/her>self.
[End.]

Then, with a swift, sudden motion, Knott slit his throat. Bubbles of blood and spit formed on the man's lips. He shuddered. Life retreated from his muscles, faltering as it went, a soldier routing from a razed city...

Knott held up the corpse until the witch had drained it of a pint of blood. Then he let it fall.
Sorrow overcame <him/her>.
<He/She>'d done what Eldest Lady asked. <He/She> put the blood away.
It had been done well.
"Knott," <FirstName> said, "You know what you have to do."

The hunter's eyes widened when he saw the gourd approach. "I thought..." he began, but then trailed off. "Ah, what does it matter?" 

Knott picked up the hunting knife.
[Continue.]
The young witch hesitated.

The conviction that this man had killed Nnenne still gripped <him/her>. But where did that conviction come from? <FirstName> couldn't tell.

The hunter waited.
The witch was ready. <He/She> picked up the skinning knife.
The hunter trembled at the touch of the blade but didn't shrink.
The witch sucked in <his/her> breath. "I won't kill you. Not yet."
"Knott," <FirstName> said, "You know what you have to do."

The conviction that this man had killed Nnenne still gripped <him/her>. But where did that conviction come from? Hadn't <he/she> felt the same with Sudder? <FirstName> couldn't tell. 

The hunter waited.
The witch was ready. <He/She> picked up the skinning knife.
The witch sucked in <his/her> breath. "I won't kill you. Not yet."
"Knott," <FirstName> said, "You know what you have to do."
The witch sucked in <his/her> breath. "I won't kill you. Not yet."
"I see."
The hunter knelt on the ground, raised his chin, and exposed his throat. "Do it." Knott, who had been standing quietly nearby, apparently unnoticed, shifted.
"You seem very calm."

He nodded.

"I've run in the woods daily, seen the seasons come and go, had enough to eat and drink. When I was young I had people I loved. In my old age I've grown wise and self-content...

"My dream gave me certainty that few others have. I'm at peace with death and the life I've had."
"It almost seems as if you've rehearsed this."

"I've had the same dream for as long as I can remember."

"A witch comes to me -- you come to me -- as I skin a deer. We converse. It's not always the same. Sometimes you're cruel, sometimes pitying, sometimes indifferent. I show you an arrow, and then you show me an arrow of the same make, but with blood on it."

"You kill me with my skinning knife."
"The arrows are the same."
"I know what that means. My life is forfeit."
[Continue.]
The hunter knelt on the ground, raised his chin, and exposed his throat. "Do it." Knott, who had been standing quietly nearby, apparently unnoticed, shifted.
"Do you have anything to say to defend yourself?"
"I do deny killing her -- not for the sake of my life, which I consider forfeit, but because I never did such a thing."

<FirstName> took out the arrow that killed Nnenne and saw it was the twin of the hunter's. The shaft had the same smoothness, the point the same sharpness, and the feathers -- goose feathers -- the same color and arrangement. Both had been made by the woodcutter's son.

The hunter said nothing.
"Why did you kill Nnenne?"
"You seem very calm."
"It almost seems as if you've rehearsed this."
"Do you have anything to say to defend yourself?"
"Very well. I can wait."
The young witch watched as the old hunter finished skinning the creature. <He/She> admired his single-mindedness.
[Continue.]
He dropped the knife. "And now, I suppose, you want to see one of my arrows?"
"If you are the killer I seek, then yes, I've come for you."
"Killer? I suppose I am. You see the kind of work I do."
[Continue.]
"Permit me to finish this," he said, still skinning the deer, "I have no children, no kin. Nothing to see finished except this last little bit of work."
"I didn't know you'd be expecting me."

"I've had the same dream for as long as I can remember."

"A witch comes to me -- you come to me -- as I skin a deer. We converse. It's not always the same. Sometimes you're cruel, sometimes pitying, sometimes indifferent. I show you an arrow, and then you show me an arrow of the same make, but with blood on it."

"You kill me with my skinning knife."
"You have dreamed a true dream."
"Permit me to finish this," he said, still skinning the deer, "I have no children, no kin. Nothing to see finished except this last little bit of work."
"And you've accepted this?"

He nodded.

"I've run in the woods daily, seen the seasons come and go, had enough to eat and drink. When I was young I had people I loved. In my old age I've grown wise and self-content...

"My dream gave me certainty that few others have. I'm at peace with death and the life I've had."
"Let me see the arrows you hunt with."
The hunter's quiver lay in the grass. He picked it up and drew forth an arrow.
"And are you at peace with murdering Nnenne?"

There was a pause. The young witch felt suddenly dizzy. Parts of the vision <he/she> had returned -- the hunter, the arrow, Nnenne --, but they were jumbled, stylized, theatrical, the work of an author, not a glimpse of breathing, human conflict.

<He/She> saw the vision of this man stalking Nnenne through the woods over again, but, just as with the vision <he/she>'d experienced with the other hunter, it seemed artificial, an imposition on <his/her> imagination.
"Your dream?"

"I've had the same dream for as long as I can remember."

"A witch comes to me -- you come to me -- as I skin a deer. We converse. It's not always the same. Sometimes you're cruel, sometimes pitying, sometimes indifferent. I show you an arrow, and then you show me an arrow of the same make, but with blood on it."

"You kill me with my skinning knife."
"I see."
The hunter knelt on the ground, raised his chin, and exposed his throat. "Do it." Knott, who had been standing quietly nearby, apparently unnoticed, shifted.
"Did you dream of Nnenne, too, before you killed her?"

There was a pause. The young witch felt suddenly dizzy. Parts of the vision <he/she> had returned -- the hunter, the arrow, Nnenne --, but they were jumbled, stylized, theatrical, the work of an author, not a glimpse of breathing, human conflict.
[Continue.]
"Nnenne?" The hunter had been speaking evenly, as if reciting a litany, but his voice changed when he said her name.
[Continue.]
"Nnenne is a person's name. It's the name of someone I've never met. I kill, as you can see --" he motioned to the deer -- "but I've never killed a person."
"You deny it, then?"
"I do deny killing her -- not for the sake of my life, which I consider forfeit, but because I never did such a thing."
"Let me see the arrows you hunt with."
The hunter's quiver lay in the grass. He picked it up and took out an arrow.
"My coming didn't surprise you, but this did. Why?"

"I've had the same dream for as long as I can remember."

"A witch comes to me -- you come to me -- as I skin a deer. We converse. It's not always the same. Sometimes you're cruel, sometimes pitying, sometimes indifferent. I show you an arrow, and then you show me an arrow of the same make, but with blood on it."

"You kill me with my skinning knife."
"I don't believe you."
"I see."

<He/She> saw the vision of this man stalking Nnenne through the woods over again, but, just as with the vision <he/she>'d experienced with the other hunter, it seemed artificial, an imposition on <his/her> imagination.
[Continue.]
"You have dreamed a true dream."
The hunter's quiver lay in the grass. He picked it up and took out an arrow.
[Continue.]

The hunter said nothing.

The hunter said nothing.
"I know."
"Why did you kill Nnenne?"

There was a pause. The young witch felt suddenly dizzy. Parts of the vision <he/she> had returned -- the hunter, the arrow, Nnenne --, but they were jumbled, stylized, theatrical, the work of an author, not a glimpse of breathing, human conflict.

<He/She> saw the vision of this man stalking Nnenne through the woods over again, but, just as with the vision <he/she>'d experienced with the other hunter, it seemed artificial, an imposition on <his/her> imagination.
[Continue.]
The hunter knelt on the ground, raised his chin, and exposed his throat. "Do it." Knott, who had been standing quietly nearby, apparently unnoticed, shifted.
"Let me see the arrows you shoot with."
The hunter's quiver lay in the grass. He picked it up and took out an arrow.

took out the arrow that killed Nnenne and saw it was the twin of the hunter's. The shaft had the same smoothness, the point the same sharpness, and the feathers -- goose feathers -- the same color and arrangement. But there was blood on the witch's.

The hunter said nothing.

<FirstName> took out the arrow that killed Nnenne and saw it was the twin of the hunter's. The shaft had the same smoothness, the point the same sharpness, and the feathers -- goose feathers -- the same color and arrangement. Both had been made by the woodcutter's son.

The hunter said nothing.
"I see."

"I've had the same dream for as long as I can remember."

"A witch comes to me -- you come to me -- as I skin a deer."
[Continue.]

The man continued:

"We converse. It's not always the same. Sometimes you're cruel, sometimes pitying, sometimes indifferent. I show you an arrow, and then you show me an arrow of the same make, but with blood on it.

"You kill me with my skinning knife."
"You have dreamed a true dream."
"And you've accepted this?"
"Did you dream of Nnenne, too, before you killed her?"
"You have dreamed a true dream."
Sudder had tried to flee his death, but this hunter had had foreseen his. Did that suggest guilt? Was the pint of blood <FirstName> had already taken the cost of justice?
[Continue.]

The man continued:

"We converse. It's not always the same. Sometimes you're cruel, sometimes pitying, sometimes indifferent. I show you an arrow, and then you show me an arrow of the same make, but with blood on it.

"You kill me with my skinning knife."

Everything about encounter with Sudder now seemed wildly off. How could have ever thought that the dour old hunter was the one to do it? The vision had been false. Nunny had lied. The conviction seized and did not let go: This was the man. "So you've come for me."
"Who are you?"
"I have," the witch said.
"If you are the killer I seek, then yes, I've come for you."
"I didn't know you'd be expecting me."
